fields.title: Marine Life: Important coastal bird and bat habitat
Every map tells a story. We help you tell yours.
Marine Life: Improved sediment and seafloor habitat maps, benthic resilence maps
Marine Life: Marine mammal population density and migration paths
Marine Life: Marine wildlife (whales, birds, turtles, bats) distribution and migration paths
Marine Life: Regional scale predictive distribution model for sea birds, sea ducks, and other bird species
Marine Life: Seasonal/anomaly maps including surface/bottom temperatures, currents, wind speed, and shear stress
Marine Life: Sea turtle population density and migration paths
Maritime: Sand, gravel, and cobble mining locations
Security: Danger Zones and Restricted Areas
Security: Department of Defense Operational Areas (OPAREAS)
Long-time fisherman keeps watch over Maryland’s coral reefs
New recreational data covers the coast
Over 138 data layers to fuel planning efforts
2015 AWEA Offshore Wind Power Conference & Exhibition
The Coast Guard maps a path toward collaboration with BOEM
Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data
Watch a recent How Tuesday webinar
Take a Tour of the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal

{"locked": false, "description": "The public is invited to attend the Council\u2019s upcoming listening session to learn more about deep sea corals in the Mid-Atlantic. Guest speaker Dr. Martha Nizinski, is a a zoologist at the NOAA Fisheries National Systematics Lab, and has played a key role in several groundbreaking investigations of deep sea habitats in the Northeast. Last summer, she was one of two lead scientists on board NOAA\u2019s research ship Okeanos Explorer during the Northeast U.S. Canyons Expedition 2013\u2014a 36-day exploration of deep sea canyons off the coast from Virginia to Maine. This year, she participated on a team of scientists that spent two weeks on board NOAA\u2019s Henry S. Bigelow surveying and collecting samples of deep-sea corals and related marine life in canyons of the northern Gulf of Maine in U.S. and Canadian waters. \r\n\r\nThe listening session will be held in conjunction with the Council's December meeting. Individuals are welcome to attend in person or via webinar at the link > http://mafmc.adobeconnect.com/december2014 ", "title": "MAFMC Listening Session: Deep Sea Corals in the Mid-Atlantic", "date": "2014-12-10", "numchild": 0, "show_in_menus": true, "live": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "depth": 4, "latest_revision_created_at": null, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "content_type": 34, "path": "0001000100020002", "owner": 2, "pk": 14, "url_path": "/home/calendar/mafmc-listening-session/", "expired": false, "slug": "mafmc-listening-session", "expire_at": null, "go_live_at": null}

{"locked": false, "description": "Map layers developed using aggregated records from NOAA's Fishing Vessel Trip Report and permit databases in consultation with commercial fishing stakeholders to illustrate the distribution and importance of commercial fishing activity by diverse communities (port, vessel type and gear group combinations). Additional attributes collected through stakeholder engagement may include information about the specific socio-economic value of fishing locations to communities.

Source: NOAA-NMFS, developed in consultation with Portal Team's commercial fishery advisory group.
Status: Data under development
Contact: Rick Lathrop, Rutgers CRSSA
Expected Date of Upload to Portal: September, 2014
Notes: Data developed using "Communities at Sea" mapping approach. Draft maps produced and currently under review by fishing industry contacts. Development of additional map layers to address key gaps including state managed fisheries will begin July 2014. {"body": "

The Need

Comprehensive regional ocean planning is essential for supporting healthy marine ecosystems and the economies of our coastal communities. \u00a0A regional approach is necessary because ocean resources are ecologically and economically linked across states and what happens in one state can impact or benefit all. \u00a0The Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO) is committed to providing the tools and resources necessary for an accessible, scientifically-informed and adaptive approach to ocean management.


With competing demands on our oceans at an all-time high, finding ways to engage all stakeholders in coastal and marine planning has never been more important. \u00a0MARCO recognizes that a robust ocean data and information management system that includes a wide range of human use, environmental, socioeconomic and regulatory data will provide the building blocks for multi-use, regional-scale ocean planning.


The Solution

The Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal is an online toolkit and resource center that consolidates available data and enables state, federal and local users to visualize and analyze ocean resources and human use information such as fishing grounds, recreational areas, shipping lanes, habitat areas, and energy sites, among others.


The Portal serves as a platform to engage all stakeholders in ocean planning from the five-state Mid-Atlantic region\u2014putting all of the essential data and state-of-the-art mapping and visualization technology into the hands of the agencies, industry, and community leaders engaged in ocean planning.

About MARCO and the Portal Project Team

The Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO) is a collaboration among the states of New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, and Virginia working to secure a balanced use of ocean resources in the Mid-Atlantic region that ensures ocean health and a robust economy. As part of their 2009 action plan, the five MARCO states agreed \u00a0to develop a regional, web-based portal for ocean planning.


The Portal Project team develops and improves this portal using funds provided by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration\u2019s (NOAA) Regional Ocean Partnership funding program. \u00a0The team is represented by Monmouth University Urban Coast Institute, Rutgers University\u2019s Edward J. Bloustein School and Center for Remote Sensing and Spatial Analysis, The Nature Conservancy, The University of Delaware\u2019s Gerard J. Mangone Center for Marine Policy, and Point 97.

{"body": "

The Need

Comprehensive regional ocean planning is essential for supporting healthy marine ecosystems and the economies of our coastal communities. \u00a0A regional approach is necessary because ocean resources are ecologically and economically linked across states and what happens in one state can impact or benefit all. \u00a0The Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO) is committed to providing the tools and resources necessary for an accessible, scientifically-informed and adaptive approach to ocean management.

With competing demands on our oceans at an all-time high, finding ways to engage all stakeholders in coastal and marine planning has never been more important. \u00a0MARCO recognizes that a robust ocean data and information management system that includes a wide range of human use, environmental, socioeconomic and regulatory data will provide the building blocks for multi-use, regional-scale ocean planning.

The Solution

The Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal is an online toolkit and resource center that consolidates available data and enables state, federal and local users to visualize and analyze ocean resources and human use information such as fishing grounds, recreational areas, shipping lanes, habitat areas, and energy sites, among others.

The Portal serves as a platform to engage all stakeholders in ocean planning from the five-state Mid-Atlantic region\u2014putting all of the essential data and state-of-the-art mapping and visualization technology into the hands of the agencies, industry, and community leaders engaged in ocean planning.

About MARCO and the Portal Project Team

The Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO) is a collaboration among the states of New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, and Virginia working to secure a balanced use of ocean resources in the Mid-Atlantic region that ensures ocean health and a robust economy. Learn more about MARCO >\u00a0http://midatlanticocean.org/

As part of their 2009 action plan, the five MARCO states agreed \u00a0to develop a regional, web-based portal for ocean planning.The Portal Project team develops and improves this portal using funds provided by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration\u2019s (NOAA) Regional Ocean Partnership funding program. \u00a0The team is represented by Monmouth University Urban Coast Institute, Rutgers University\u2019s Edward J. Bloustein School and Center for Remote Sensing and Spatial Analysis, The Nature Conservancy, The University of Delaware\u2019s Gerard J. Mangone Center for Marine Policy, and Point 97.

", "locked": false, "title": "About Us", "numchild": 0, "show_in_menus": false, "live": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "depth": 3, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-09T00:34:36.269Z", "has_unpublished_changes": true, "content_type": 31, "path": "000100010005", "owner": 2, "pk": 28, "url_path": "/home/about-us/", "expired": false, "slug": "about-us", "expire_at": null, "go_live_at": null}

The Solution

The Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal is an online toolkit and resource center that consolidates available data and enables state, federal and local users to visualize and analyze ocean resources and human use information such as fishing grounds, recreational areas, shipping lanes, habitat areas, and energy sites, among others.

The Portal serves as a platform to engage all stakeholders in ocean planning from the five-state Mid-Atlantic region\u2014putting all of the essential data and state-of-the-art mapping and visualization technology into the hands of the agencies, industry, and community leaders engaged in ocean planning.

About MARCO and the Portal Project Team

The Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO) is a collaboration among the states of New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, and Virginia working to secure a balanced use of ocean resources in the Mid-Atlantic region that ensures ocean health and a robust economy. Learn more about MARCO >\u00a0http://midatlanticocean.org/

As part of their 2009 action plan, the five MARCO states agreed \u00a0to develop a regional, web-based portal for ocean planning.The Portal Project team develops and improves this portal using funds provided by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration\u2019s (NOAA) Regional Ocean Partnership funding program. \u00a0The team is represented by Monmouth University Urban Coast Institute, Rutgers University\u2019s Edward J. Bloustein School and Center for Remote Sensing and Spatial Analysis, The Nature Conservancy, The University of Delaware\u2019s Gerard J. Mangone Center for Marine Policy, and Point 97.

{"body": "

The Need

Comprehensive regional ocean planning is essential for supporting healthy marine ecosystems and the economies of our coastal communities. \u00a0A regional approach is necessary because ocean resources are ecologically and economically linked across states and what happens in one state can impact or benefit all. \u00a0The Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO) is committed to providing the tools and resources necessary for an accessible, scientifically-informed and adaptive approach to ocean management.

With competing demands on our oceans at an all-time high, finding ways to engage all stakeholders in coastal and marine planning has never been more important. \u00a0MARCO recognizes that a robust ocean data and information management system that includes a wide range of human use, environmental, socioeconomic and regulatory data will provide the building blocks for multi-use, regional-scale ocean planning.

{"locked": false, "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "sections": [{"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\u201cForty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.


\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas. Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid- Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "", "map_state": "http://portal.midatlanticocean.org/visualize/#x=-72.73&y=38.25&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&basemap=ESRI+Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 46, "page": null}], "numchild": 0, "show_in_menus": false, "live": true, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "depth": 4, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-15T22:27:27.882Z", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "content_type": 33, "path": "0001000100010004", "owner": 2, "pk": 42, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/marylands-coral-reefs/", "expired": false, "slug": "marylands-coral-reefs", "expire_at": null, "go_live_at": null}

From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\u201cForty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.


\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas. Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid- Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

{"search_description": "", "owner": 2, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-18T16:57:24.131Z", "description": "Population density distribution estimates (actual and modeled) and delineation of seasonal migratory pathways for sea turtles through Mid-Atlantic.\u00a0

Source: Multiple sources include new survey and modeling projects by NOAA (AMAPPS), Biodiversity Research Inst., VA Aquarium, and Duke University (OBIS)\u00a0

{"search_description": "", "owner": 2, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-18T16:37:45.790Z", "description": "Map layers developed using aggregated records from NOAA's Fishing Vessel Trip Report and permit databases in consultation with commercial fishing stakeholders to illustrate the distribution and importance of commercial fishing activity by diverse communities (port, vessel type and gear group combinations). Source: NOAA-NMFS, developed in consultation with Portal Team's commercial fishery advisory group.\u00a0
Status: Data under development\u00a0
Contact: Rick Lathrop, Rutgers CRSSA\u00a0
Notes: Data developed using \"Communities at Sea\" mapping approach. Draft maps produced and currently under review by fishing industry contacts. Development of additional map layers to address key gaps including state managed fisheries will begin July 2014. Additional potential data sources include NOAA's Vessel Monitoring System, state agency collected data and participatory mapping projects with fishermen.

{"search_description": "", "owner": 2, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-09T16:51:20.944Z", "description": "This fall, NOAA intends to release a revised version of Danger Zones and Restricted Areas based on the most current areas designated as such in the CFR. These areas are either high risk areas where hazardous operations occur on full time or intermittent basis or high security areas to protect Government property, usually for national security purposes, that are either closed to or restrict public access.\u00a0


Source: NOAA is digitizing the areas as described in the Code of Federal Regulations\u00a0

Status: Data under development\u00a0

Contact: NOAA Coastal Services Center\u00a0

Notes: NOAA is creating a national geospatial database of the Danger Zones and Restricted Areas based on the most current Code of Federal Regulations for the Cadastre.

{"search_description": "", "owner": 2, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-09T22:43:17.465Z", "description": "The public is invited to attend the Council\u2019s upcoming listening session to learn more about deep sea corals in the Mid-Atlantic. Guest speaker Dr. Martha Nizinski, is a a zoologist at the NOAA Fisheries National Systematics Lab, and has played a key role in several groundbreaking investigations of deep sea habitats in the Northeast. Last summer, she was one of two lead scientists on board NOAA\u2019s research ship Okeanos Explorer during the Northeast U.S. Canyons Expedition 2013\u2014a 36-day exploration of deep sea canyons off the coast from Virginia to Maine. This year, she participated on a team of scientists that spent two weeks on board NOAA\u2019s Henry S. Bigelow surveying and collecting samples of deep-sea corals and related marine life in canyons of the northern Gulf of Maine in U.S. and Canadian waters. \n\nThe listening session will be held in conjunction with the Council's December meeting. Individuals are welcome to attend in person or via webinar at the link > http://mafmc.adobeconnect.com/december2014 ", "title": "MAFMC Listening Session: Deep Sea Corals in the Mid-Atlantic", "seo_title": "", "slug": "mafmc-listening-session", "live": true, "location": "", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "feature_image": 18, "end_date": null, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 34, "show_in_menus": true, "date": "2014-12-05", "path": "0001000100020002", "url_path": "/home/calendar/mafmc-listening-session/", "expired": false, "pk": 14, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"search_description": "", "owner": 2, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-18T22:20:46.902Z", "description": "The public is invited to attend the Council\u2019s upcoming listening session to learn more about deep sea corals in the Mid-Atlantic. Guest speaker Dr. Martha Nizinski, is a a zoologist at the NOAA Fisheries National Systematics Lab, and has played a key role in several groundbreaking investigations of deep sea habitats in the Northeast. Last summer, she was one of two lead scientists on board NOAA\u2019s research ship Okeanos Explorer during the Northeast U.S. Canyons Expedition 2013\u2014a 36-day exploration of deep sea canyons off the coast from Virginia to Maine. This year, she participated on a team of scientists that spent two weeks on board NOAA\u2019s Henry S. Bigelow surveying and collecting samples of deep-sea corals and related marine life in canyons of the northern Gulf of Maine in U.S. and Canadian waters. \n\nThe listening session will be held in conjunction with the Council's December meeting. Individuals are welcome to attend in person or via webinar at the link > http://mafmc.adobeconnect.com/december2014


http://www.mafmc.org/meetings/

{"search_description": "", "owner": 2, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-18T22:50:54.078Z", "description": "The public is invited to attend the Council\u2019s upcoming listening session to learn more about deep sea corals in the Mid-Atlantic. Guest speaker Dr. Martha Nizinski, is a a zoologist at the NOAA Fisheries National Systematics Lab, and has played a key role in several groundbreaking investigations of deep sea habitats in the Northeast. Last summer, she was one of two lead scientists on board NOAA\u2019s research ship Okeanos Explorer during the Northeast U.S. Canyons Expedition 2013\u2014a 36-day exploration of deep sea canyons off the coast from Virginia to Maine. This year, she participated on a team of scientists that spent two weeks on board NOAA\u2019s Henry S. Bigelow surveying and collecting samples of deep-sea corals and related marine life in canyons of the northern Gulf of Maine in U.S. and Canadian waters. \n\nThe listening session will be held in conjunction with the Council's December meeting. Individuals are welcome to attend in person or via webinar at the link > http://mafmc.adobeconnect.com/december2014


http://www.mafmc.org/meetings/

Location

The Royal Sonesta Harbor Court Baltimore\u00a0

550 Light St.

Baltimore, MD\u00a0

Telephone: (410) 234-0550

{"locked": false, "feature_image": 25, "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "sections": [{"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\u201cForty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.


\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas. Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid- Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

{"locked": false, "feature_image": 25, "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "sections": [{"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\u201cForty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.


\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas. Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid- Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Fish Populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.17&y=37.87&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.36&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas. Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.


", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.17&y=37.87&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.36&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid- Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.21&y=37.68&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

{"locked": false, "feature_image": 25, "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "sections": [{"body": "

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.17&y=37.87&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.36&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.17&y=37.87&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.36&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. ", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.17&y=37.87&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.36&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

{"locked": false, "feature_image": 25, "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "sections": [{"body": "

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.21&y=37.30&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.36&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.21&y=37.30&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.21&y=37.30&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

{"locked": false, "feature_image": 25, "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "sections": [{"body": "

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=6&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

{"locked": false, "feature_image": null, "title": "New Recreational Data Covers the Coast", "sections": [{"body": "It\u2019s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it\u2019s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

\u201cSurfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we\u2019re always looking for data,\u201d Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.\u201cRecreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn\u2019t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.\u201d

\u201cWe've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we\u2019ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,\u201d says Gove. \u201cRecreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. It\u2019s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it\u2019s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

\u201cSurfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we\u2019re always looking for data,\u201d Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.\u201cRecreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn\u2019t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.\u201d

\u201cWe've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we\u2019ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,\u201d says Gove. \u201cRecreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.\u201d

It\u2019s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it\u2019s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

\u201cSurfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we\u2019re always looking for data,\u201d Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.\u201cRecreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn\u2019t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.\u201d

\u201cWe've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.\u201d

", "title": "Charting the unknown", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.24&y=38.93&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&basemap=Ocean&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

\u201cThe portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it\u2019s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.\u201d

", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.60&y=40.01&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents\u2019 house.\u00a0 At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.\u00a0 And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation\u2019s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she\u2019ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse \u2013 a place she\u2019s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

\u201cWhen you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,\u201d she says.

\u201cWhatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,\u201d says Bell. \u201cWhatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what\u2019s happening in the waves and currents.\u00a0 That will affect what we are able to do in the water.\u201d

", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.80&y=40.22&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=3&themes[ids][]=5&themes[ids][]=1&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=4&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

\u201cThat information is very helpful for us,\u201d says Gove, \u201cbecause now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there\u2019s an economic benefit to those areas.\u201d

", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.62&y=38.71&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=3&themes[ids][]=5&themes[ids][]=1&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "numchild": 0, "show_in_menus": false, "live": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "depth": 4, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-19T20:10:54.089Z", "has_unpublished_changes": true, "content_type": 33, "path": "0001000100010005", "owner": 3, "pk": 46, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "expired": false, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "expire_at": null, "go_live_at": null}
