", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.60&y=40.01&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents\u2019 house.\u00a0 At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.\u00a0 And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation\u2019s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she\u2019ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse \u2013 a place she\u2019s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

\u201cWhen you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,\u201d she says.

\u201cWhatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,\u201d says Bell. \u201cWhatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what\u2019s happening in the waves and currents.\u00a0 That will affect what we are able to do in the water.\u201d

", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.80&y=40.22&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=3&themes[ids][]=5&themes[ids][]=1&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=4&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

\u201cThat information is very helpful for us,\u201d says Gove, \u201cbecause now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there\u2019s an economic benefit to those areas.\u201d

", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.33&y=40.48&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=3&themes[ids][]=5&themes[ids][]=1&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=4&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "numchild": 0, "show_in_menus": false, "live": false, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "depth": 4, "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-19T20:15:27.801Z", "has_unpublished_changes": true, "content_type": 33, "path": "0001000100010005", "owner": 3, "pk": 46, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "expired": false, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "expire_at": null, "go_live_at": null}

It\u2019s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it\u2019s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

\u201cSurfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we\u2019re always looking for data,\u201d Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.\u201cRecreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn\u2019t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.\u201d

\u201cWe've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we\u2019ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,\u201d says Gove. \u201cRecreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.\u201d

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. “We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” says Gove. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”

A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

{"locked": false, "feature_image": null, "title": "New Recreational Data Covers the Coast", "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "title": "Charting the unknown", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.24&y=38.93&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&basemap=Ocean&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”

“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” says Gove. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”

", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

{"locked": false, "feature_image": null, "title": "New Recreational Data Covers the Coast", "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "title": "Charting the unknown", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”

“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” says Gove. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”

", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

{"search_description": "", "hook": "How can place-based partnerships protect the places we play in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-19T21:05:41.235Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "title": "New Recreational Data Covers the Coast", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "title": "Charting the unknown", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”

“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” says Gove. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”

", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "explore_title": "", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"search_description": "", "hook": "How fishermen are charting the course for coral habitat restoration?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-19T19:31:12.541Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/marylands-coral-reefs/", "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "seo_title": "", "owner": 2, "slug": "marylands-coral-reefs", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "sections": [{"body": "

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.19&y=38.14&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

{"search_description": "", "hook": "How fishermen are charting the course for coral habitat restoration?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-19T22:12:52.115Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/marylands-coral-reefs/", "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "seo_title": "", "owner": 2, "slug": "marylands-coral-reefs", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "sections": [{"body": "

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.19&y=38.14&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-77.05&y=39.37&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 46, "page": null}], "explore_url": "", "feature_image": 25, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010004", "explore_title": "", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"search_description": "", "hook": "Fishermen are navigating the waters between fish habitat restoration and potential wind energy development. Can the Mid-Atlantic have both?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-19T22:12:54.468Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/marylands-coral-reefs/", "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "seo_title": "", "owner": 2, "slug": "marylands-coral-reefs", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "sections": [{"body": "

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.19&y=38.14&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-77.05&y=39.37&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 46, "page": null}], "explore_url": "", "feature_image": 25, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010004", "explore_title": "", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"search_description": "", "hook": "Fishermen are navigating the waters between fish habitat restoration and potential wind energy development. Can the Mid-Atlantic have both?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-19T22:57:28.257Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/marylands-coral-reefs/", "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "seo_title": "", "owner": 2, "slug": "marylands-coral-reefs", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "sections": [{"body": "

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.19&y=38.14&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-77.05&y=39.37&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 46, "page": null}], "explore_url": "", "feature_image": 25, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010004", "explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"search_description": "", "hook": "Fishermen are navigating the waters between fish habitat restoration and potential wind energy development. Can the Mid-Atlantic have both?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-19T22:57:30.195Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/marylands-coral-reefs/", "title": "Long-Time Fisherman Keeps Watch Over Maryland\u2019s Coral Reefs", "seo_title": "", "owner": 2, "slug": "marylands-coral-reefs", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "sections": [{"body": "

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.19&y=38.14&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restorating reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-77.05&y=39.37&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 46, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-77.05&y=39.37&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 25, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010004", "explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"search_description": "", "hook": "How can place-based partnerships protect the places we play in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-19T22:10:49.223Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "title": "New Recreational Data Covers the Coast", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "title": "Charting the unknown", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”

“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” says Gove. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”

", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "explore_title": "", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"search_description": "", "hook": "How can place-based partnerships protect the places we play in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-24T02:02:09.344Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "title": "New Recreational Data Covers the Coast", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "title": "Charting the unknown", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”

“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”

", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2014-12-24T02:13:24.295Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "title": "New Recreational Data Covers the Coast", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "title": "Charting the unknown", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”

“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”

", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"locked": false, "description": "The Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO) has developed the following list that identifies some of the highest priority unmet ocean planning data needs as well as data currently under development, but not yet available for the Mid-Atlantic Region.

If you have spatial data that might address a data gap, are aware of plans to collect data that might address specific identified data gap, or have an additional ocean planning data need that we have not yet identified, please contact us at portal@midatlanticocean.org.

{"search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-06T00:03:12.062Z", "go_live_at": null, "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "title": "New Recreational Data Covers the Coast", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "title": "Charting the unknown", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”

“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”
