{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Navigating the waters between fish habitat restoration and potential wind energy development. Can the Mid-Atlantic have both?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-14T17:21:02.471Z", "description": "", "title": "Long-time fisherman keeps watch over Maryland\u2019s coral reefs", "seo_title": "", "owner": 2, "slug": "marylands-coral-reefs", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.19&y=38.14&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restoring reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-71.69&y=38.98&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 46, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 25, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010004", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/marylands-coral-reefs/", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"explore_title": "", "search_description": "", "hook": "", "latest_revision_created_at": null, "description": "", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) are a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real-time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard\u2019s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. This process was done for the entire track line database as well as subsets of the database by vessel group (cargo vessels, tanker vessels, tug/tow vessels and passenger vessels).", "title": "2012 AIS Track Line Density Grids", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.11&y=37.01&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 232, "page": 53}], "explore_url": "", "feature_image": null, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010009", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data/", "expired": false, "pk": 53, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"explore_title": "", "search_description": "", "hook": "", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T21:50:15.374Z", "description": "", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above).

Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner).

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds.

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. ", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations.

In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. {"explore_title": "", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T22:30:17.299Z", "description": "", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

{"explore_title": "", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T22:33:09.665Z", "description": "", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "Increased understanding emerges with increased access to information.  The Ocean Data Portal's Marine Planner presents just that opportunity.  In this use case, a wealth of spatial maritime information published by multiple agency and non-governmental partners is overlaid to create a picture of maritime traffic and use in the Mid-Atlantic.  When combined with an overview of the most recent Wind Development Planning Area spatial information, a rich opportunity for exploration and discussion emerges.  Explore the data layers below and directly in Marine Planner to zoom and pan.", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations. 

", "title": "North Atlantic Right Whale Seasonal Management Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=39.95&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 8, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Need a description for this wind energy data like the other maritime sections.", "title": "BOEM Wind Planning Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.55&y=39.72&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 9, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) are a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real-time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. This process was done for the entire track line database as well as subsets of the database by vessel group (cargo vessels, tanker vessels, tug/tow vessels and passenger vessels).", "title": "2012 AIS Track Line Density Grids", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.11&y=37.01&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 232, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": null, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010009", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data/", "expired": false, "pk": 53, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations.

In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. {"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T22:38:06.605Z", "description": "", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "Increased understanding emerges with increased access to information.  The Ocean Data Portal's Marine Planner presents just that opportunity.  In this use case, a wealth of spatial maritime information published by multiple agency and non-governmental partners is overlaid to create a picture of maritime traffic and use in the Mid-Atlantic.  When combined with an overview of the most recent Wind Development Planning Area spatial information, a rich opportunity for exploration and discussion emerges.  Explore the data layers below and directly in Marine Planner to zoom and pan.", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T22:43:56.562Z", "description": "", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "Increased understanding emerges with increased access to information.  The Ocean Data Portal's Marine Planner presents just that opportunity.  In this use case, a wealth of spatial maritime information published by multiple agency and non-governmental partners is overlaid to create a picture of maritime traffic and use in the Mid-Atlantic.  When combined with an overview of the most recent Wind Development Planning Area spatial information, a rich opportunity for exploration and discussion emerges.  Explore the data layers below and directly in Marine Planner to zoom and pan.", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations. 

", "title": "North Atlantic Right Whale Seasonal Management Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=39.95&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=123&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 8, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Need a description for this wind energy data like the other maritime sections.", "title": "BOEM Wind Planning Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.55&y=39.72&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 9, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) are a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real-time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds.

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). {"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T22:50:28.319Z", "description": "", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "Increased understanding emerges with increased access to information.  The Ocean Data Portal's Marine Planner presents just that opportunity.  In this use case, a wealth of spatial maritime information published by multiple agency and non-governmental partners is overlaid to create a picture of maritime traffic and use in the Mid-Atlantic.  When combined with an overview of the most recent Wind Development Planning Area spatial information, a rich opportunity for exploration and discussion emerges.  Explore the data layers below and directly in Marine Planner to zoom and pan.", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation.
