Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations.

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T22:53:38.304Z", "description": "", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "Increased understanding emerges with increased access to information.  The Ocean Data Portal's Marine Planner presents just that opportunity.  In this use case, a wealth of spatial maritime information published by multiple agency and non-governmental partners is overlaid to create a picture of maritime traffic and use in the Mid-Atlantic.  When combined with an overview of the most recent Wind Development Planning Area spatial information, a rich opportunity for exploration and discussion emerges.  Explore the data layers below and directly in Marine Planner to zoom and pan.", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations. 

", "title": "North Atlantic Right Whale Seasonal Management Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=39.95&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 8, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Need a description for this wind energy data like the other maritime sections.", "title": "BOEM Wind Planning Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.55&y=39.72&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 9, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) are a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real-time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. This process was done for the entire track line database as well as subsets of the database by vessel group (cargo vessels, tanker vessels, tug/tow vessels and passenger vessels).", "title": "2012 AIS Track Line Density Grids", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.11&y=37.01&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 232, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": null, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010009", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data/", "expired": false, "pk": 53, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T22:58:55.273Z", "description": "", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "Increased understanding emerges with increased access to information.  The Ocean Data Portal's Marine Planner presents just that opportunity.  In this use case, a wealth of spatial maritime information published by multiple agency and non-governmental partners is overlaid to create a picture of maritime traffic and use in the Mid-Atlantic.  When combined with an overview of the most recent Wind Development Planning Area spatial information, a rich opportunity for exploration and discussion emerges.  Explore the data layers below and directly in Marine Planner to zoom and pan.", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations. 

", "title": "North Atlantic Right Whale Seasonal Management Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=39.95&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 8, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Need a description for this wind energy data like the other maritime sections.", "title": "BOEM Wind Planning Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.55&y=39.72&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 9, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) are a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real-time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. This process was done for the entire track line database as well as subsets of the database by vessel group (cargo vessels, tanker vessels, tug/tow vessels and passenger vessels).", "title": "2012 AIS Track Line Density Grids", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.11&y=37.01&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 232, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 39, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010009", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data/", "expired": false, "pk": 53, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

This process was done for the entire track line database as well as subsets of the database by vessel group (cargo vessels, tanker vessels, tug/tow vessels and passenger vessels).", "title": "2012 AIS Track Line Density Grids", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.11&y=37.01&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 232, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 39, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010009", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data/", "expired": false, "pk": 53, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T23:07:48.267Z", "description": "This would be the space that could provide a teaser and brief summary/abstract of the ocean story to entice site visitors to click on the story and explore more.", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "Increased understanding emerges with increased access to information.  The Ocean Data Portal's Marine Planner presents just that opportunity.  In this use case, a wealth of spatial maritime information published by multiple agency and non-governmental partners is overlaid to create a picture of maritime traffic and use in the Mid-Atlantic.  When combined with an overview of the most recent Wind Development Planning Area spatial information, a rich opportunity for exploration and discussion emerges.  Explore the data layers below and directly in Marine Planner to zoom and pan.", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "title": "Maintained Channels", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations. 

", "title": "North Atlantic Right Whale Seasonal Management Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=39.95&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 8, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Need a description for this wind energy data like the other maritime sections.", "title": "BOEM Wind Planning Areas", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.55&y=39.72&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 9, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) are a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real-time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. This process was done for the entire track line database as well as subsets of the database by vessel group (cargo vessels, tanker vessels, tug/tow vessels and passenger vessels).", "title": "2012 AIS Track Line Density Grids", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.11&y=37.01&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 232, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 39, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010009", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data/", "expired": false, "pk": 53, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Navigating the waters between fish habitat restoration and potential wind energy development. Can the Mid-Atlantic have both?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-16T21:41:05.968Z", "description": "In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. \u00a0For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies.\u00a0", "title": "Long-time fisherman keeps watch over Maryland\u2019s coral reefs", "seo_title": "", "owner": 2, "slug": "marylands-coral-reefs", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

\u201cIt\u2019s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic \u2013 huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven\u2019t made it into science literature,\u201d he says. \u201cLots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.\u201d

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.\u00a0

", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.19&y=38.14&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

\u201cI\u2019m not opposed to wind \u2013 we need to look at alternative energy, no question.\u201d And, he adds, \u201cThere\u2019s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.\u201d

", "title": "Restoring reef habitat", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, \u201ca critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.\u201d

For more information about the State of Maryland\u2019s Artificial Reef Initiative visit\u00a0http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland\u2019s coast visit\u00a0ocreefs.org.

", "title": "Advancing science", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

\u201cNo radios or boom boxes allowed,\u201d says Captain Monty Hawkins. \u201cI\u2019m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It\u2019s about the people around you and the quality of experience.\u201d

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland\u2019s coast, he\u2019s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

\"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.\u201d Hawkins says. \u201cNow we\u2019re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.\u201d

", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-71.69&y=38.98&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 46, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 25, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010004", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/marylands-coral-reefs/", "expired": false, "pk": 42, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-15T19:24:36.026Z", "description": "It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.", "title": "New recreational data covers the coast", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "title": "Charting the unknown", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”


“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”


", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"explore_title": "View these data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can maps help federal agencies communicate in new ways?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-15T19:10:13.948Z", "description": "Recently, with the help of the Data Portal, a key stakeholder \u2013 the Coast Guard \u2013 was able to use the best available data, which they helped create, to participate in important ocean planning dialogue via map.", "title": "The Coast Guard maps a path toward collaboration with BOEM", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "coast-guard-maps-path-toward-collaboration-boem", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

With the help of the Data Portal team the Coast Guard was able to import this data into Marine Planner, giving it a visual presence in the landscape of other ocean uses including the proposed wind planning areas both in New Jersey and elsewhere.

\"Having those data in such a ready-made format where they can go to one place and look at some of these problem areas between leasing of off-shore wind, subsequent construction of turbines and shipping was really helpful to the Coast Guard,\" Chricton said.

Said Walters, \"The need for data to work in the current world cannot be understated. For us and the Bureau of Ocean and Energy Management, AIS data is critical to ensuring safety and navigation off-shore.

\"Once the data was made usable, the Coast Guard was able to respond to the Bureau of Ocean and Energy Management during an important public comment period \u2013 not just via a letter, but also via map.

\"We were thrilled that they could use the Portal to help them communicate some really important information to another federal agency,\" Chricton said.

", "title": "New data drives new conversations", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.13&y=39.36&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=143&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=98&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=93&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=92&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Apart from tracking shipping data, the Coast Guard has recognizes several other ways the data in the Portal can help them achieve their missions.

\"One of the other aspects that has helped us out was the mapping of coral,\" Walters said. \"We had no understanding of where the essential fish habitat was, what it was nor again where the coral was. If we\u2019re looking at the creation of off-shore anchorages and aids to navigation we need to know that the bottom is clear of coral.\"

In addition to knowing where cold water coral exists, Walters said the accumulation of data around fishing is also very helpful for the Coast Guard.

\"In years past it\u2019s been very difficult to obtain any information about where fishing activity occurs,\" Walters said. \"Through the efforts of MARCO and its stakeholder outreach I think fishermen both commercial and recreational have been able to fill a vacuum. We had no visibility about how fishing activity interacted with commercial shipping.\"

\"Essentially the portal provides one stop shopping to determine multiple objectives,\" Walters said.

", "title": "Exploring new uses, partnerships through mapping ocean data", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.15&y=39.65&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=30&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=106&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.8&dls[]=105&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=128&dls[]=true&dls[]=1&dls[]=58&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=135&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=2&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The success of ocean planning in the Mid-Atlantic relies on the ability for disparate groups to effectively communicate their concerns and needs to one another. Recently, with the help of the Data Portal, a key stakeholder \u2013 the Coast Guard \u2013 was able to use the best available data, which they helped create, to participate in important ocean planning dialogue via map.

", "title": "", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.13&y=39.36&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=128&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.8&dls[]=64&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=143&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=98&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=93&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=92&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 200, "page": null}, {"body": "

In the byways of the busy Mid-Atlantic the Coast Guard plays an important role in maintaining safety and security for vessels of all kinds.

\"The ocean is getting very crowded,\" said former 5th district Chief of Waterways Management Division John Walters. \"The areas of intersection between various users is ever increasing, there is ever a demand for more activity on the ocean.\"

Walters, now retired, said the Coast Guard recognized a pressing need to engage in ocean planning with the emergence of wind planning areas off the coast of the New Jersey in 2009 \u2013 visualized in the map above.

\"With the development of off-shore wind energy, we needed to know where shipping was and how the placement of wind turbines or wind farms could affect shipping,\" said Walters.

", "title": "Approaching potential conflict in a busy ocean", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-72.54&y=39.31&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=93&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.77&dls[]=92&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 201, "page": null}, {"body": "

Luckily, the Coast Guard had been gathering a data set that would help them participate in the wind energy conversation in a whole new way.

\"It's only been in the last few years that they've been collecting what has becomes billions of data points on the live locations of all of the vessels that are required to have AIS transponders,\u201d said Portal team member and lead scientist for The Nature Conservancy Gwynn Chricton. \u201cWhen they set out and they up that system they never suspected that these data would suddenly have this huge utility and relevance for ocean planning that there would be a demand to use these data for anything beyond managing vessel traffic and safety and navigation.\"

\"AIS is a signal that has become a treasure trove of information,\" Walters said. \"We're not looking at one or two ships anymore; we're able to look at a whole year's worth of data to determine where shipping is occurring. Prior to AIS that information was very limited. A shipping company may know about its own ships, but it wouldn\u2019t know anything about other ships. The Coast Guard would only know of transits if it was positively informed by a vessel in transit.\"

", "title": "Mapping a data goldmine", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-72.54&y=39.31&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=143&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 202, "page": null}], "explore_url": "", "feature_image": null, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010008", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/coast-guard-maps-path-toward-collaboration-boem/", "expired": false, "pk": 52, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"body": "

The Portal serves as a platform to engage all stakeholders in ocean planning from the five-state Mid-Atlantic region—putting all of the essential data and state-of-the-art mapping and visualization technology into the hands of the agencies, industry, and community leaders engaged in ocean planning.

The portal team

The Portal Project team develops and improves this portal using funds provided by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Regional Ocean Partnership funding program. The team is represented by the Monmouth University Urban Coast Institute, Rutgers University’s Edward J. Bloustein School and Center for Remote Sensing and Spatial Analysis, The Nature Conservancy, The University of Delaware’s Gerard J. Mangone Center for Marine Policy, and Point 97.

MARCO

The Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO) is a collaboration among the states of New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, and Virginia working to secure a balanced use of ocean resources in the Mid-Atlantic region that ensures ocean health and a robust economy. 

MARCO leverages existing state and federal resources, knowledge, and partnerships to build a stronger base of information and experience to make well-informed decisions in the best interest of the states and their constituents. Leading MARCO’s efforts is the MARCO Management Board, which comprises senior coastal managers and policy advisors from each of the five member states and is responsible for implementing MARCO’s regional priorities. By working together, while recognizing the partners’ varying respective interests and needs, MARCO provides the states with expanded capacity to address pressing management challenges to improve ocean health, achieve sustainable use of ocean spaces and resources, and grow the vital ocean-based economy.

Learn more at midatlanticocean.org.

Our partners

With competing demands on our oceans at an all-time high, finding ways to engage all stakeholders in coastal and marine planning has never been more important.  MARCO recognizes that a robust ocean data and information management system that includes a wide range of human use, environmental, socioeconomic and regulatory data will provide the building blocks for multi-use, regional-scale ocean planning.

MARACOOS

While the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal organizes data and  information provided by a variety of sources (e.g. NOAA, BOEM, State Fish and Wildlife services, et al.) to support ocean planning and enable ocean stakeholders to visualize the data alongside other regionally-specific ocean data, the Mid-Atlantic Regional Association Coastal Ocean Observing System (MARACOOS) provides a live assets map for access to real time ocean observations, nowcasts, and forecasts of oceanographic factors such as temperature, currents and wind that ocean users depend on.  The Portal team and MARACOOS are working together to identify how real time information can be used to create new map layers that that will be included in the Ocean Data Portal and used to inform better ocean planning. 

Learn more at maracoos.org.

", "locked": false, "description": "

The Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal is an online toolkit and resource center that consolidates available data and enables state, federal and local users to visualize and analyze ocean resources and human use information such as fishing grounds, recreational areas, shipping lanes, habitat areas, and energy sites, among others.

", "title": "About the Portal", "numchild": 0, "show_in_menus": false, "live": true, "seo_title": "", "search_description": "", "depth": 3, "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-14T06:25:06.677Z", "has_unpublished_changes": false, "content_type": 31, "path": "000100010005", "owner": 2, "pk": 28, "url_path": "/home/about-us/", "expired": false, "slug": "about-portal", "expire_at": null, "go_live_at": null}

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-21T00:39:49.244Z", "description": "It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.", "title": "New recreational data covers the coast", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Charting the unknown", "media_image": 2, "media_position": "right", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”


“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”


", "media_caption": "", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

{"body": "

With competing demands on our oceans at an all-time high, finding ways to engage all stakeholders in coastal and marine planning has never been more important. Mid-Atlantic Regional Council on the Ocean (MARCO)  recognizes that a robust ocean data and information management system that includes a wide range of human use, environmental, socioeconomic and regulatory data will provide the building blocks for multi-use, regional-scale ocean planning. The Portal serves as a platform to engage all stakeholders in ocean planning from the five-state Mid-Atlantic region—putting all of the essential data and state-of-the-art mapping and visualization technology into the hands of the agencies, industry, and community leaders engaged in ocean planning.

The portal team

The Portal Project team develops and improves this portal using funds provided by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Regional Ocean Partnership funding program. The team is represented by the Monmouth University Urban Coast Institute, Rutgers University’s Edward J. Bloustein School and Center for Remote Sensing and Spatial Analysis, The Nature Conservancy, The University of Delaware’s Gerard J. Mangone Center for Marine Policy, and Point 97.

MARCO

MARCO is a collaboration among the states of New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, and Virginia working to secure a balanced use of ocean resources in the Mid-Atlantic region that ensures ocean health and a robust economy. 

MARCO leverages existing state and federal resources, knowledge, and partnerships to build a stronger base of information and experience to make well-informed decisions in the best interest of the states and their constituents. Leading MARCO’s efforts is the MARCO Management Board, which comprises senior coastal managers and policy advisors from each of the five member states and is responsible for implementing MARCO’s regional priorities. By working together, while recognizing the partners’ varying respective interests and needs, MARCO provides the states with expanded capacity to address pressing management challenges to improve ocean health, achieve sustainable use of ocean spaces and resources, and grow the vital ocean-based economy.

Learn more at midatlanticocean.org.

Our partners

MARACOOS

While the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal organizes data and  information provided by a variety of sources (e.g. NOAA, BOEM, State Fish and Wildlife services, et al.) to support ocean planning and enable ocean stakeholders to visualize the data alongside other regionally-specific ocean data, the Mid-Atlantic Regional Association Coastal Ocean Observing System (MARACOOS) provides a live assets map for access to real time ocean observations, nowcasts, and forecasts of oceanographic factors such as temperature, currents and wind that ocean users depend on.  The Portal team and MARACOOS are working together to identify how real time information can be used to create new map layers that that will be included in the Ocean Data Portal and used to inform better ocean planning. 

Learn more at maracoos.org.

", "locked": false, "description": "

The Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal is an online toolkit and resource center that consolidates available data and enables state, federal and local users to visualize and analyze ocean resources and human use information such as fishing grounds, recreational areas, shipping lanes, habitat areas, and energy sites, among others.
