As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, “a critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.”

For more information about the State of Maryland’s Artificial Reef Initiative visit http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland’s coast visit ocreefs.org.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Advancing science", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

“No radios or boom boxes allowed,” says Captain Monty Hawkins. “I’m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It’s about the people around you and the quality of experience.”

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland’s coast, he’s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.” Hawkins says. “Now we’re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.”

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, “a critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. ", "media_caption": "", "title": "Advancing science", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

“No radios or boom boxes allowed,” says Captain Monty Hawkins. “I’m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It’s about the people around you and the quality of experience.”


Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland’s coast, he’s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.” Hawkins says. “Now we’re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.”

“No radios or boom boxes allowed,” says Captain Monty Hawkins. “I’m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It’s about the people around you and the quality of experience.”

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland’s coast, he’s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.” Hawkins says. “Now we’re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.”

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, “a critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. For more information about the State of Maryland’s Artificial Reef Initiative visit http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland’s coast visit ocreefs.org.

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

“No radios or boom boxes allowed,” says Captain Monty Hawkins. “I’m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It’s about the people around you and the quality of experience.”

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland’s coast, he’s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.” Hawkins says. “Now we’re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.”

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. “It’s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic – huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven’t made it into science literature,” he says. “Lots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.”

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Changes in fish populations", "media_image": 71, "media_position": "right", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.19&y=38.14&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

“I’m not opposed to wind – we need to look at alternative energy, no question.” And, he adds, “There’s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.”

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Restoring reef habitat", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.32&y=38.05&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=93&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, “a critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.”

For more information about the State of Maryland’s Artificial Reef Initiative visit http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland’s coast visit ocreefs.org.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Advancing science", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

“No radios or boom boxes allowed,” says Captain Monty Hawkins. “I’m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It’s about the people around you and the quality of experience.”

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland’s coast, he’s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.” Hawkins says. “Now we’re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.”

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

“It’s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic – huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven’t made it into science literature,” he says. “Lots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.”

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.

Whether over a shipwreck or a natural rocky reef, schools of fish teemed around the myriad hard and soft coral structures signaling hope for what populations could be with a more focused effort on restoration.

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

“I’m not opposed to wind – we need to look at alternative energy, no question.” And, he adds, “There’s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.”

As he continues his work plotting the remaining footprint of natural corals with NOAA, MARCO, The Nature Conservancy and the State of Maryland, Hawkins says the Mid-Atlantic Ocean Data Portal will be, “a critical piece of the puzzle to advance fish restoration and to understand existing habitat. MARCO is all about advancing the science.”

For more information about the State of Maryland’s Artificial Reef Initiative visit http://www.dnr.state.md.us/fisheries/reefs/

For information on marine reef building off Maryland’s coast visit ocreefs.org.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Advancing science", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

“No radios or boom boxes allowed,” says Captain Monty Hawkins. “I’m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It’s about the people around you and the quality of experience.”

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland’s coast, he’s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.” Hawkins says. “Now we’re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.”

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

“I’m not opposed to wind – we need to look at alternative energy, no question.” And, he adds, “There’s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.”

", "media_caption": "Members of the Ocean City Reef Foundation build artificial reefs with concrete blocks", "title": "Advancing science", "media_image": 76, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

“No radios or boom boxes allowed,” says Captain Monty Hawkins. “I’m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It’s about the people around you and the quality of experience.”

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland’s coast, he’s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.” Hawkins says. “Now we’re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.”

While he is passionate about restoring reef habitat, the Captain readily acknowledges there are many other industries that rely on the bounty of the ocean environment, including the energy sector.

“I’m not opposed to wind – we need to look at alternative energy, no question.” And, he adds, “There’s a recognition that these reefs are good for fish. In an immediate sense, nobody associated with wind would want to drive a pile through them.”

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Advancing science", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.85&y=39.02&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=20&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=1&dls%5B%5D=58&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.33&dls%5B%5D=90&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

When you book a trip on the Morning Star out of Ocean City, Maryland, there are some rules:

“No radios or boom boxes allowed,” says Captain Monty Hawkins. “I’m trying to get as close to old-time fishing as I can get. It’s about the people around you and the quality of experience.”

Of course, part of that quality experience is being able to find fish for his clients and help them land a solid catch. In the nearly 35 years Captain Hawkins has been fishing off Maryland’s coast, he’s seen an increase in some fish populations as well as a decline in others. From the mid-1990s to early-2000s he saw a tremendous increase in natural reef habitat with a corresponding increase in black sea bass populations.

"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.” Hawkins says. “Now we’re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.”

"Forty or 50 years ago it was no problem finding black sea bass over an abundance of soft corals. Skippers could find good bottom with simple navigation; a compass alone would get you to a reef.” Hawkins says. “Now we’re using GPS to find remnants of those once much larger habitats. Important hard-bottom communities are absent throughout the Mid-Atlantic.”

For more than 15 years he has been documenting the increases and decline of fish populations as it correlates with the increases and declines of reef habitat and coral colonies. He has been an active participant in building artificial reefs to support new populations for nearly 30 years. By his estimation, only 10 percent of historic near-shore reef structures exist today.

“It’s crazy how little has been researched in the Mid-Atlantic – huge fisheries are associated with coral reefs, but reef communities haven’t made it into science literature,” he says. “Lots of fisheries science and restoration is going on, but nothing about our near-shore corals.”

In a 2010 YouTube video, one of three he has produced documenting some of his own findings, Hawkins used an underwater camera to show the stark contrast between reefs that had been scraped clean of coral habitat, and natural or restored areas.

{"explore_title": "View these data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can maps help federal agencies communicate in new ways?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-31T01:09:54.607Z", "description": "Recently, with the help of the Data Portal, a key stakeholder \u2013 the Coast Guard \u2013 was able to help create data and use it to participate in important ocean planning dialogue via map.", "title": "The Coast Guard maps a path toward collaboration with BOEM", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "coast-guard-maps-path-toward-collaboration-boem", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

With the help of the Data Portal team the Coast Guard was able to import this data into Marine Planner, giving it a visual presence in the landscape of other ocean uses including the proposed wind planning areas both in New Jersey and elsewhere.

\"Having those data in such a ready-made format where they can go to one place and look at some of these problem areas between leasing of off-shore wind, subsequent construction of turbines and shipping was really helpful to the Coast Guard,\" Chricton said.

Said Walters, \"The need for data to work in the current world cannot be understated. For us and the Bureau of Ocean and Energy Management, AIS data is critical to ensuring safety and navigation off-shore.

\"Once the data was made usable, the Coast Guard was able to respond to the Bureau of Ocean and Energy Management during an important public comment period \u2013 not just via a letter, but also via map.

\"We were thrilled that they could use the Portal to help them communicate some really important information to another federal agency,\" Chricton said.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "New data drives new conversations", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.13&y=39.36&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=143&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=98&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=93&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=92&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Apart from tracking shipping data, the Coast Guard has recognizes several other ways the data in the Portal can help them achieve their missions.

\"One of the other aspects that has helped us out was the mapping of coral,\" Walters said. \"We had no understanding of where the essential fish habitat was, what it was nor again where the coral was. If we\u2019re looking at the creation of off-shore anchorages and aids to navigation we need to know that the bottom is clear of coral.\"

In addition to knowing where cold water coral exists, Walters said the accumulation of data around fishing is also very helpful for the Coast Guard.

\"In years past it\u2019s been very difficult to obtain any information about where fishing activity occurs,\" Walters said. \"Through the efforts of MARCO and its stakeholder outreach I think fishermen both commercial and recreational have been able to fill a vacuum. We had no visibility about how fishing activity interacted with commercial shipping.\"

\"Essentially the portal provides one stop shopping to determine multiple objectives,\" Walters said.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Exploring new uses, partnerships through mapping ocean data", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.15&y=39.65&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=30&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=106&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.8&dls[]=105&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=128&dls[]=true&dls[]=1&dls[]=58&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=135&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=2&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The success of ocean planning in the Mid-Atlantic relies on the ability for disparate groups to effectively communicate their concerns and needs to one another. Recently, with the help of the Data Portal, a key stakeholder \u2013 the Coast Guard \u2013 was able to use the best available data, which they helped create, to participate in important ocean planning dialogue via map.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.13&y=39.36&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=128&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.8&dls[]=64&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=143&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=98&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=93&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=92&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 200, "page": null}, {"body": "

In the byways of the busy Mid-Atlantic the Coast Guard plays an important role in maintaining safety and security for vessels of all kinds.

\"The ocean is getting very crowded,\" said former 5th district Chief of Waterways Management Division John Walters. \"The areas of intersection between various users is ever increasing, there is ever a demand for more activity on the ocean.\"

Walters, now retired, said the Coast Guard recognized a pressing need to engage in ocean planning with the emergence of wind planning areas off the coast of the New Jersey in 2009 \u2013 visualized in the map above.

\"With the development of off-shore wind energy, we needed to know where shipping was and how the placement of wind turbines or wind farms could affect shipping,\" said Walters.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Approaching potential conflict in a busy ocean", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-72.54&y=39.31&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=93&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.77&dls[]=92&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 201, "page": null}, {"body": "

Luckily, the Coast Guard had been gathering a data set that would help them participate in the wind energy conversation in a whole new way.

\"It's only been in the last few years that they've been collecting what has becomes billions of data points on the live locations of all of the vessels that are required to have AIS transponders,\u201d said Portal team member and lead scientist for The Nature Conservancy Gwynn Chricton. \u201cWhen they set out and they up that system they never suspected that these data would suddenly have this huge utility and relevance for ocean planning that there would be a demand to use these data for anything beyond managing vessel traffic and safety and navigation.\"

\"AIS is a signal that has become a treasure trove of information,\" Walters said. \"We're not looking at one or two ships anymore; we're able to look at a whole year's worth of data to determine where shipping is occurring. Prior to AIS that information was very limited. A shipping company may know about its own ships, but it wouldn\u2019t know anything about other ships. The Coast Guard would only know of transits if it was positively informed by a vessel in transit.\"

{"explore_title": "View these data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can maps help federal agencies communicate in new ways?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T19:49:20.605Z", "description": "Recently, with the help of the Data Portal, a key stakeholder \u2013 the Coast Guard \u2013 was able to help create data and use it to participate in important ocean planning dialogue via map.", "title": "The Coast Guard maps a path toward collaboration with BOEM", "seo_title": "", "owner": 3, "slug": "coast-guard-maps-path-toward-collaboration-boem", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

With the help of the Data Portal team the Coast Guard was able to import this data into Marine Planner, giving it a visual presence in the landscape of other ocean uses including the proposed wind planning areas both in New Jersey and elsewhere.

\"Having those data in such a ready-made format where they can go to one place and look at some of these problem areas between leasing of off-shore wind, subsequent construction of turbines and shipping was really helpful to the Coast Guard,\" Chricton said.

Said Walters, \"The need for data to work in the current world cannot be understated. For us and the Bureau of Ocean and Energy Management, AIS data is critical to ensuring safety and navigation off-shore.

\"Once the data was made usable, the Coast Guard was able to respond to the Bureau of Ocean and Energy Management during an important public comment period \u2013 not just via a letter, but also via map.

\"We were thrilled that they could use the Portal to help them communicate some really important information to another federal agency,\" Chricton said.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "New data drives new conversations", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.13&y=39.36&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=143&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=98&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=93&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=92&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=8&themes[ids][]=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Apart from tracking shipping data, the Coast Guard has recognizes several other ways the data in the Portal can help them achieve their missions.

\"One of the other aspects that has helped us out was the mapping of coral,\" Walters said. \"We had no understanding of where the essential fish habitat was, what it was nor again where the coral was. If we\u2019re looking at the creation of off-shore anchorages and aids to navigation we need to know that the bottom is clear of coral.\"

In addition to knowing where cold water coral exists, Walters said the accumulation of data around fishing is also very helpful for the Coast Guard.

\"In years past it\u2019s been very difficult to obtain any information about where fishing activity occurs,\" Walters said. \"Through the efforts of MARCO and its stakeholder outreach I think fishermen both commercial and recreational have been able to fill a vacuum. We had no visibility about how fishing activity interacted with commercial shipping.\"

\"Essentially the portal provides one stop shopping to determine multiple objectives,\" Walters said.

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T17:28:16.426Z", "description": "It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.", "title": "New recreational data covers the coast", "seo_title": "Surfrider coastal recreation data", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "


", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "full", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”


“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”


", "media_caption": "", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "media_caption": "Kayaker Christine Bell enjoying the Mid-Atlantic coast", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "media_image": 2, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”


“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and their partners at Point 97, The Nature Conservancy, and Monmouth University collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”


", "media_caption": "", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "media_caption": "Kayaker Christine Bell enjoying the Mid-Atlantic coast", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "media_image": 2, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T21:44:47.628Z", "description": "Through a collaborative partnership between the Surfrider Foundation, Monmouth University, The Nature Conservancy, and Point 97 there is now new, non-consumptive recreational use data available for the Mid-Atlantic region.", "title": "New recreational data covers the coast", "seo_title": "Surfrider coastal recreation data", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "full", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”


“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

Over the course of the survey, Surfrider and collected 1,500 responses, gathering more than 22,000 data points in the process.

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”


", "media_caption": "", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "media_caption": "Kayaker Christine Bell enjoying the Mid-Atlantic coast", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "media_image": 2, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T21:45:42.594Z", "description": "Through a collaborative partnership between the Surfrider Foundation, Monmouth University, The Nature Conservancy, and Point 97 there is now new, non-consumptive recreational use data available for the Mid-Atlantic region.", "title": "New recreational data covers the coast", "seo_title": "Surfrider coastal recreation data", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

Using a web-based survey tool, the group collected nearly 1,500 complete surveys resulting in 22,000 unique data points. And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform planning or management decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region..

There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”


“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.”

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "media_caption": "Kayaker Christine Bell enjoying the Mid-Atlantic coast", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "media_image": 2, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T22:15:16.178Z", "description": "Through a collaborative partnership between the Surfrider Foundation, Monmouth University, The Nature Conservancy, and Point 97 there is now new, non-consumptive recreational use data available for the Mid-Atlantic region.", "title": "New recreational data covers the coast", "seo_title": "Surfrider coastal recreation data", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

Using a web-based survey tool, the group collected nearly 1,500 complete surveys resulting in 22,000 unique data points. And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform planning or management decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

Mid-Atlantic respondents spent an average of $71.06 per coastal visit, and the most popular coastal activities include surfing, biking, hiking, and photography.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "full", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”


“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.” 

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T22:38:14.313Z", "description": "Through a collaborative partnership between the Surfrider Foundation, Monmouth University, The Nature Conservancy, and Point 97 there is now new, non-consumptive recreational use data available for the Mid-Atlantic region.", "title": "New recreational data covers the coast", "seo_title": "Surfrider coastal recreation data", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

Using a web-based survey tool, the group collected nearly 1,500 complete surveys resulting in 22,000 unique data points. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "full", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”


“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.” 

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”


", "media_caption": "", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "media_caption": "Kayaker Christine Bell enjoying the Mid-Atlantic coast", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "media_image": 2, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"explore_title": "View the data catalog", "search_description": "", "hook": "Over 138 data layers to fuel planning efforts - and counting...", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T17:29:39.407Z", "description": "", "title": "Over 138 data layers to fuel planning efforts", "seo_title": "", "owner": 2, "slug": "over-138-data-layers-fuel-planning-efforts", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

All ocean stakeholders need to take part in identifying our region\u2019s ocean planning priorities. Whether through reviewing existing information or contributing new data to fill critical gaps, your participation in the MARCO Portal project will help set the stage for future management decisions that balance diverse goals and provide lasting benefits for our region.

Please contact us if you have existing data we could use or would like to partner with MARCO in\u00a0developing one or more of the data sets mentioned above. Email: portal@midatlanticocean.org

", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.16&y=39.28&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=73&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.94&dls%5B%5D=58&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=7&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=5&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=1&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "The Portal gathers the best-available, regionally relevant data and presents it in a user-friendly platform to engage all stakeholders in ocean planning from the five state Mid-Atlantic region \u2014 putting all of the essential data and\u00a0state-of-the art mapping and visualization technology into the hands of the agencies, industry, and community leaders engaged in ocean planning.


Both the data and the mapping tool, Marine Planner, are organized around industry sectors and focus-area themes highly relevant to planning in the Mid-Atlantic, including:\u00a0Fishing, Renewable Energy, Maritime, Marine Life, Security, Recreation,\u00a0and\u00a0Administrative Boundaries.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.16&y=39.28&z=7&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=73&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=91&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.94&dls%5B%5D=58&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=4&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=2&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=7&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=5&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=1&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 163, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/data-catalog/", "feature_image": 17, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010006", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/over-138-data-layers-fuel-planning-efforts/", "expired": false, "pk": 47, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "How can the places we play be protected in the landscape of regional planning?", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T22:50:11.032Z", "description": "Through a collaborative partnership between the Surfrider Foundation, Monmouth University, The Nature Conservancy, and Point 97 there is now new, non-consumptive recreational use data available for the Mid-Atlantic region.", "title": "New recreational data covers the coast", "seo_title": "Surfrider coastal recreation data", "owner": 3, "slug": "new-recreational-data-covers-coast", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

It’s fairly obvious that the ocean is a mecca for recreation: Whether it’s kayaking, surfing, sailing or hiking nearly everyone has a favorite coastal activity. However, until recently, the true influence of recreational use in the region had gone unquantified.

Using a web-based survey tool, the group collected nearly 1,500 surveys resulting in 22,000 unique data points. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "full", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": 144, "page": null}, {"body": "

“Surfrider works on a lot of coastal issues so we’re always looking for data,” says Matt Gove, Policy Manager for the Surfrider Foundation in the Mid-Atlantic.“Recreational users are really varied from beach goers and wildlife viewers and coastal hikers to kayakers and divers. There really wasn’t any data that existed before for recreational use and that was a big reason we wanted to get involved.”


“We've become kind of a go to organization around the country for collecting this recreational data. Just in the last three or four years we’ve done a study in Oregon and are starting ones in Washington state and in the Northeast,” Gove says. “Recreational use data is hard to collect, people are dispersed. With other sectors like shipping or fishing there are regulations that require them to collect data. Recreation data in the Mid-Atlantic was kind of a blank slate.” 

“The portal is really helpful because all the data is there in one place and we can see it. And, for someone like me with no GIS experience, it’s really easy to make a map, share a link to it, and use it to explain to people where we did the survey and what it entails.”


", "media_caption": "", "title": "Bringing recreational data to life", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.16&y=40.31&z=9&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 145, "page": null}, {"body": "

For people like New Jersey native Christine Bell, who has spent most of her life on the coast, doing just about every water-related activity you could think of, it was easy to pinpoint her favorite places on the coast and in the ocean:

She grew up spending summers on the beach at Bay Head, near her grandparents’ house.  At 14, she was a beach cleaner; at 18, she was ushered into the lifeguard stand just north at Sea Girt, paddling and kayaking as part of her training. A competitive swimmer, she frequented the open ocean mile races sponsored by towns up and down the coast, and during college she would train during the summer months by going for ocean swims in Long Branch. She surfed the breaks throughout Monmouth County. She went to a special magnet high school focused on marine science on the slender spit of Sandy Hook.  And she dove the wrecks offshore, eventually becoming a certified dive instructor.

But if this longtime leader in The Surfrider Foundation’s Jersey Shore chapter has to choose a favorite ocean location: she’ll take the rolling beaches of Sea Girt, nestled next to the old Victorian lighthouse – a place she’s guarded and played, a place where everyone knows her name.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Mapping personal, place-based connections", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=40.12&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": 146, "page": null}, {"body": "

Bell, 28, was among the kinds of ocean users Surfrider and their partners were talking to.

A land use planner by day, Bell understands that rich maps that include recreational data will help bridge differing uses on the ocean.

“When you show things in relation to one another on paper you can see the connections,” she says.

“Whatever happens offshore will affect divers and fishermen,” says Bell. “Whatever happens on the coast and near shore, in terms of rebuilding, beach replenishment, and other uses, will change what’s happening in the waves and currents.  That will affect what we are able to do in the water.”

", "media_caption": "Kayaker Christine Bell enjoying the Mid-Atlantic coast", "title": "Building new bridges between ocean users", "media_image": 2, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": 147, "page": null}, {"body": "

And now, for the first time through Marine Planner, regional scale data layers are available for planners and managers to better-inform decisions that impact or influence surfing, boating, sight-seeing and other non-consumptive activities throughout the region.

In addition to illuminating where and how people were recreating, the data collected in the survey also provides new economic information - indicating that people recreating on the coast spend more than $70 per person per day.

“That information is very helpful for us,” says Gove, “because now we know people are coming to coastal towns and spending lots of money, so if we protect these resources there’s an economic benefit to those areas.”

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Protecting the places we play", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.39&y=40.62&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=91&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=145&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=138&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&themes[ids][]=4&themes[ids][]=8&tab=active&legends=true&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": 148, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-74.57&y=39.11&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls[]=true&dls[]=0.5&dls[]=137&basemap=Ocean&themes[ids][]=7&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 2, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010005", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/new-recreational-data-covers-coast/", "expired": false, "pk": 46, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

All ocean stakeholders need to take part in identifying our region\u2019s ocean planning priorities. {"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-01-21T00:35:30.590Z", "description": "


", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to one of the most vital shipping corridors in the country as well as an abundant supply of clean, renewable wind, wave, and tidal energy that could help meet the growing electricity demand in the region, while reducing carbon emissions.  


As bot industries continue to grow as important economic drivers for our region, members of the Portal team prepared an exploration of the available data layers to help [confirm details with Gwynn ]

", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning.
