Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "media_caption": "", "title": "Maintained Channels", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "North Atlantic Right Whale Seasonal Management Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=39.95&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 8, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Need a description for this wind energy data like the other maritime sections.", "media_caption": "", "title": "BOEM Wind Planning Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.55&y=39.72&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 9, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) are a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real-time. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. {"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T23:42:00.656Z", "description": "


", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to one of the most vital shipping corridors in the country as well as an abundant supply of clean, renewable wind, wave, and tidal energy that could help meet the growing electricity demand in the region, while reducing carbon emissions.  

As both industries continue to grow in economic and environmental importance for our region, advance your understanding of these issues by exploring the available data layers in this increasingly crowded space.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "media_caption": "", "title": "Maintained Channels", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "North Atlantic Right Whale Seasonal Management Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=39.95&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 8, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Need a description for this wind energy data like the other maritime sections.", "media_caption": "", "title": "BOEM Wind Planning Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.55&y=39.72&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 9, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) are a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real-time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. {"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T23:55:18.281Z", "description": "

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to one of the most vital shipping corridors in the country as well as an abundant supply of clean, renewable wind, wave, and tidal energy that could help meet the growing electricity demand in the region, while reducing carbon emissions.  

As both industries continue to grow in economic and environmental importance for our region, advance your understanding of these issues by exploring the available data layers in this increasingly crowded space.

", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "


", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "media_caption": "", "title": "Maintained Channels", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations.

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-04T23:55:54.245Z", "description": "

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to one of the most vital shipping corridors in the country as well as an abundant supply of clean, renewable wind, wave, and tidal energy that could help meet the growing electricity demand in the region, while reducing carbon emissions.  

As both industries continue to grow in economic and environmental importance for our region, advance your understanding of these issues by exploring the available data layers in this increasingly crowded space.

", "title": "Ports and Shipping Sector Geospatial Data", "seo_title": "", "owner": 4, "slug": "ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data", "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "go_live_at": null, "sections": [{"body": "


", "media_caption": "", "title": "", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 0, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "These data were derived from NOAA Electronic Navigation Charts (ENC) and translated and stored in a geodatabase by NOAA Coastal Services Center for the purposes of regional ocean planning. In the MARCO Portal, these data are displayed in three depth classes: 0-35’, 35-45’, and >45’. The channel limits on the NOAA ENC data were originally compiled from the channel limits portrayed on USACE surveys as well as being digitized from paper and raster charts. Ultimately the source of the maintained channel data is USACE.", "media_caption": "", "title": "Maintained Channels", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.43&y=39.21&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 2, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 and currently provides them via MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above). 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds.

{"explore_title": "View data layers in Marine Planner", "search_description": "", "hook": "Overlaying maritime and wind energy planning data reveals patterns of multiple use", "latest_revision_created_at": "2015-02-05T00:01:52.623Z", "description": "

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to one of the most vital shipping corridors in the country as well as an abundant supply of clean, renewable wind, wave, and tidal energy that could help meet the growing electricity demand in the region, while reducing carbon emissions.  

As both industries continue to grow in economic and environmental importance for our region, advance your understanding of these issues by exploring the available data layers in this increasingly crowded space.

NOAA Coastal Services Center published these data in 2010 on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal imports these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. These data include Shipping Safety Fairways, Traffic Separation Zones, and Precautionary Areas. Definitions for each are provided below. 

Shipping Safety Fairways: A lane or corridor in which no artificial island or fixed structure, whether temporary or permanent, will be permitted. Temporary underwater obstacles may be permitted under certain conditions described for specific areas in Subpart B. Aids to navigation approved by the U.S. Coast Guard may be established in a fairway. 

Traffic Separation Zones: A designated routing measure which is aimed at the separation of opposing streams of traffic by appropriate means and by the establishment of traffic lanes. Traffic lanes are an area within defined limits in which specific traffic flow is established. Designates traffic areas to provide access routes for vessels proceeding to and from U.S. ports. 

Precautionary Areas: A routing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution.

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-75.07&y=38.75&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 3, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

These points were extracted from the Port Facility database maintained by the US Army Corps of Engineers Navigation Data Center. This database contains a list of all facility types (dock, anchorage, etc.) that may be reported as the origin or destination of commercial waterborne vessel moves. Data included is for all facility types that were available for use during the previous two years. For the purposes of the MARCO portal, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University filtered the nationwide database to include only those facilities relevant to the four major Mid-Atlantic ports of Virginia, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York/New Jersey. Facilities that serve primarily fishing boats or recreational craft were also excluded, as were points in open water. Attributes were added for ownership type (public, private or military) (map view above) and general commodity category (explore Marine Planner). 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Points (by Ownership Type)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.36&y=36.88&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 4, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Using the Port Facility Points data described above, The Nature Conservancy and Rutgers University captured land-based areas associated with these points primarily from individual municipalities’ tax parcel data. In Philadelphia, port facility and freight center areas were incorporated directly from the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission’s Philly Freight Finder database and in the case of Baltimore and the Port of Virginia, public terminal boundaries received from these respective port authorities were incorporated directly. Attributes were also added for ownership type (public, private or military) (explore Marine Planner) and general commodity category (map view above).

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Port Facility Areas (by Commodity Category)", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.56&y=39.22&z=12&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.98&dls%5B%5D=123&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 5, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

Aids to navigation are a database maintained by the US Coast Guard from which NOAA Coastal Services Center created a geospatial database for display on MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. Included are structures intended to assist a navigator to determine position or safe course, or to warn of dangers or obstructions to navigation. This dataset includes lights, signals, buoys, day beacons, and other aids to navigation. These data are intended for coastal and ocean use planning and not for navigation. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Aids to Navigation", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.15&y=37.06&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=128&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 6, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

NOAA Coastal Services Center created the Anchorage Areas geospatial database from both the National Geodectic Survey Continually Updated Shoreline Product and the Office of Coast Survey’s Raster Nautical Chart to host these data in MarineCadastre.gov. The MARCO Portal consumes these data directly from MarineCadastre.gov. The areas described in subpart A (33 U.S.C. 100) are designated as special anchorage areas. Vessels of less than 20 meters are not required to exhibit anchor lights or shapes required by rule 30 of the Inland Navigation Rules (33 U.S.C. 2030). The areas described in subpart B are designated as anchorage grounds. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "Anchorage Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.33&y=36.96&z=11&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 7, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "

The originator of these data is NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). These data represent Seasonal Management Area locations where regulations implement speed restrictions in shipping areas at certain times of the year along the coast of the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The purpose of the regulations is to reduce the likelihood of deaths and serious injuries to endangered North Atlantic right whales that result from collisions with ships as designated by 73 FR 60173, October 10, 2008, Rules and Regulations. 

", "media_caption": "", "title": "North Atlantic Right Whale Seasonal Management Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.96&y=39.95&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=8&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 8, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "This data set represents the most recent changes for the Wind Development Planning Areas in the Atlantic. Wind Planning Areas in this dataset represent up to seven different types of announcements within the US Federal Register (e.g. Call Area, Wind Energy Area, Request for Interest, Proposed Sale Notice Area) that can be used to show the current status of an area that is being considered for Wind Power Development.", "media_caption": "", "title": "BOEM Wind Planning Areas", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.55&y=39.72&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Ocean&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=data&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 9, "pk": null, "page": null}, {"body": "Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) are a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real-time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal and ocean planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to re-task and make available some of the most important records from the U.S. Coast Guard’s national network of AIS receivers. Information such as location and ship type have been extracted from the raw data and prepared as track lines by NOAA Coastal Services Center. The Nature Conservancy then used the track lines to generate density grids for the MARCO Portal. AIS track lines were converted to density grids using a 100m output cell size. This process was done for the entire track line database as well as subsets of the database by vessel group (cargo vessels, tanker vessels, tug/tow vessels and passenger vessels).", "media_caption": "", "title": "2012 AIS Track Line Density Grids", "media_image": null, "media_position": "left", "map_state": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-76.11&y=37.01&z=10&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "media_embed_url": "", "sort_order": 1, "pk": 232, "page": null}], "explore_url": "http://midatlantic.point97.io/visualize/#x=-73.86&y=39.58&z=8&logo=true&controls=true&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=143&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=122&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=64&dls%5B%5D=false&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=126&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.8&dls%5B%5D=105&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=106&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=125&dls%5B%5D=true&dls%5B%5D=0.5&dls%5B%5D=92&basemap=Satellite&themes%5Bids%5D%5B%5D=3&tab=active&legends=false&layers=true", "feature_image": 39, "numchild": 0, "content_type": 33, "show_in_menus": false, "path": "0001000100010009", "url_path": "/home/ocean-stories/ports-and-shipping-sector-geospatial-data/", "expired": false, "pk": 53, "locked": false, "depth": 4, "expire_at": null}

{"pk": 59, "path": "00010001000C", "depth": 3, "numchild": 0, "title": "About", "draft_title": "About", "slug": "about", "content_type": 41, "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/about/", "owner": 6, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": null, "last_published_at": null, "latest_revision_created_at": null, "live_revision": null, "description": "", "body": "

ABOUT THE PORTAL

The West Coast Ocean Data Portal is a project to increase discovery and connectivity of ocean and coastal data and people to better inform regional resource management, policy development, and ocean planning. The Portal informs priority West Coast ocean issues such as tracking sources and patterns of marine debris, adaptation to sea-level rise, understanding impacts of ocean acidification on our coasts, and marine planning.

"}

{"pk": 64, "path": "00010001000F", "depth": 3, "numchild": 0, "title": "Inform", "draft_title": "Inform", "slug": "inform", "content_type": 91, "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/inform/", "owner": 6, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": null, "last_published_at": null, "latest_revision_created_at": null, "live_revision": null, "body": "[{\"type\": \"item\", \"value\": {\"cta_title\": \"INFORMING OCEAN AND COASTAL HEALTH DECISIONS\", \"cta_content\": \"

Threats including marine debris, sea-level rise, and changing ocean conditions will continue to affect ocean and coastal areas across the West Coast. Tapping into the West Coast's rich data resources and providing tools to visualize and map that information, the West Coast Ocean Data Portal helps ocean and coastal managers make sound decisions to improve ocean health. You can start exploring the issues of marine debris, regional planning, and changing ocean conditions.

\", \"cta_link\": \"\", \"width\": 7}, \"id\": \"7a570741-e8e2-4316-bc2b-b1ef9b5bfba8\"}]"}

{"pk": 59, "path": "000100020004", "depth": 3, "numchild": 0, "title": "About", "draft_title": "About", "slug": "about", "content_type": 41, "live": false, "has_unpublished_changes": true, "url_path": "/home-new/about/", "owner": 6, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": null, "last_published_at": null, "latest_revision_created_at": "2019-07-19T19:44:01.654Z", "live_revision": null, "description": "", "body": "

ABOUT THE PORTAL

The West Coast Ocean Data Portal is a project to increase discovery and connectivity of ocean and coastal data and people to better inform regional resource management, policy development, and ocean planning. The Portal informs priority West Coast ocean issues such as tracking sources and patterns of marine debris, adaptation to sea-level rise, understanding impacts of ocean acidification on our coasts, and marine planning.

"}

[{"type": "item", "value": {"cta_title": "INFORMING OCEAN AND COASTAL HEALTH DECISIONS", "cta_content": "

Threats including marine debris, sea-level rise, and changing ocean conditions will continue to affect ocean and coastal areas across the West Coast. Tapping into the West Coast's rich data resources and providing tools to visualize and map that information, the West Coast Ocean Data Portal helps ocean and coastal managers make sound decisions to improve ocean health. You can start exploring the issues of marine debris, regional planning, and changing ocean conditions.

Connect to data producers and users

The West Coast Ocean Data Network is dedicated to increasing communication between state and federal agencies, tribes, universities, NGOs, and industry to leverage resources for new data collection, develop data best management practices, conduct trainings, and ensure compatibility of regional datasets.

CSW is an open standard created by the Open Geospatial Consortium for discovering, browsing, and querying metadata records from a data catalog. This portal uses CSW to harvest many of the published resources from our network providers, and in turn publishes a CSW interface that you can connect to. Access our CSW interface at the following URL using your favorite CSW client:
